p: Two different transmission cycles exist for the CHIKV, namely the sylvatic cycle seen mainly in Africa and the urban cycle that was initially seen in Asia but is also now found in Africa. CHIKV is maintained in nature by the sylvatic cycle, with monkeys, rodents, baboons and birds serving as reservoir hosts. Human beings replace these wild animals as reservoirs during periods of epidemics [ 10] The most effective vector for human transmission is Ae. aegypti [ 18], while Ae. furcifor- taylori is the predominant species for transmission in animals [ 18]. Although Ae. albopictus is readily infected by CHIKV, its transmissibility is low [ 19]. However a mutation found in the E1 protein of CHIKV (A226V) has enabled this virus to eliminate its cholesterol dependence, thereby achieving better viral uptake, replication and transmission by Ae.. albopictus, which has a wider geographical distribution than Ae. aegypti. This led to an explosive outbreak of CHIK in the Indian Subcontinent post 2006 [ 20]. The vector competency of Ae. albopictus has also been enhanced by adaptive mutations in CHIKV involving E2 and E3 substitutions which enhance the initial infection of the Ae. albopictus midgut by CHIKV [ 47].
